part1.setup: Character begins walking without destination after receiving life-changing news (job loss, death, betrayal)
part1.action: Protagonist deambulates through familiar streets that now feel alien

part2.development: The act of aimless walking reveals the character's fractured internal state through external observations
part2.action: Physical details of the walk mirror psychological fragmentation - broken windows, closed shops, changing neighborhoods
part2.emotion: Gradual awakening to surroundings, pattern recognition, memories surfacing

part3.resolution: Through the wandering, character reaches unexpected clarity about what they've lost or what they must do
part3.action: Walking leads to specific location (childhood home, first apartment, old workplace) that crystallizes decision
part3.emotion: Bittersweet acceptance, renewed sense of direction, ironic clarity through directionless walking

literaryDevices: Pathetic fallacy - weather/environment reflects mental state
Stream of consciousness narration during walking
Urban landscape as mirror of psychological terrain
Circular route ending where it began (physical vs psychological change)
exampleNarrativeHooks: Three hours after the funeral, Miguel found himself deambulando through streets he no longer recognized.
She had been deambulando for so long, the hospital corridors had become more familiar than her own apartment.
Every night since the layoff, he deambulaba through the financial district, watching others rush to jobs that no longer existed for him.

part1.action: Exile or curse forces character to errar through lands seeking redemption, answer, or return

deambularStory.title: Las calles no recuerdan
deambularStory.part1: After 20 years abroad, Lucía returns to find her childhood neighborhood transformed by gentrification. Unable to sleep, she deambula through streets where nothing remains as she remembered.
deambularStory.part2: Night after night, her walking reveals layers of the neighborhood's transformation. She overhears conversations, observes new inhabitants, sees her past overlaid on the present like a palimpsest.
deambularStory.part3: On her final night before returning abroad, she discovers the old bakery survived in a basement space. The encounter with the baker's grandson crystallizes her understanding: memory lives in people, not places.

vagarStory.title: El que no tiene norte
vagarStory.part1: After the dictatorship, Tomás can't settle back into normal life. What begins as a short trip to visit his sister becomes five years vagando through South America, unable to return home.
vagarStory.part2: His wandering takes him from Tierra del Fuego to Colombia, through odd jobs, brief relationships, and encounters with others similarly displaced by history and trauma.
vagarStory.part3: In a Chilean port town, he meets his daughter—now an adult—who has been searching for him. The reunion forces him to choose between continuing to vagar or facing the past he's been moving to escape.

errarStory.title: Los años de errancia
errarStory.part1: Colonial Mexico, 1680: A Spanish soldier betrays his Indigenous guide, leading to a massacre. Cursed by the dying shaman, he begins to errar through lands that shift between historical periods.
errarStory.part2: Across centuries, he witnesses consequences of conquest, always arriving too late to prevent suffering, unable to die, forced to understand the gravity of his original error.
errarStory.part3: In present-day, in the same location as the original betrayal, he encounters a descendant of the murdered guide. Only by bearing full witness to their story can he finally end his errancia.

researchConclusions: All three literary walking verbs operate on different scales of space, time, and meaning, offering distinct narrative opportunities.
Deambular is ideal for contemporary urban narratives exploring alienation and identity in modern Latin American cities.
Vagar suits expansive narratives of displacement, exile, and search for belonging across geographical and temporal spans.
Errar demands elevated literary style but offers unique opportunity for allegory, classical resonance, and moral-philosophical exploration.
The verbs can be combined within single narrative to show progression: deambular (immediate crisis) → vagar (extended searching) → errar (mythological/eternal significance).
Cultural context matters: Latin American literary tradition (especially magical realism and exile literature) provides rich resonance for all three terms.
Each verb naturally suggests different narrative structures, prose styles, and thematic emphases.
Contemporary authors should consider reader expectations: deambular reads as naturally literary, vagar as traditional/classical, errar as deliberately archaic/elevated.
